title: How to Make Rose Tea

steps.headline: Select pesticide-free petals.
steps.description: You'll need a good amount, at least 1 cup and preferably 2 cups. Clean the petals in a colander placed under running water.

steps.headline: Place the 1 to 2 cups rose petals in a saucepan filled with 3 cups of water.
Boil for five minutes.
steps.description: Then strain and pour into cups or mugs.

steps.headline: Sweeten with honey or enjoy as it is.
Dry the rose petals.
steps.description: If you are not buying dried rose petals from a tea store, make your own. You will need to be certain that the variety of rose petals you grow are sweet tasting rather than bitter. If unsure, ask your local horticultural specialists for advice. Pick the rose petals and make sure they are free of dew. Half fill the net bag and close with an elastic. Hang the bag in a warm, dry and dark place to dry. This will take anywhere from a few days to a week, depending on the humidity of your environment.

steps.headline: Make the tea.
steps.description: Once the petals have dried, you can prepare the tea. Combine equal parts rose leaves and equal parts green powder tea.

steps.headline: Store in an airtight, opaque container suitable for tea.
Make a cup of tea following the instructions for the green powder tea.
steps.description: Add honey to sweeten if desired.

steps.headline: Select a quality black tea of your liking.
steps.description: The roses will scent it but it must be a good tea to begin with, so that you enjoy the blend. You could also choose oolong tea, a blend of black and green, with their lovely, rich and fruity flavours.

steps.headline: Place the tea leaves and rose petals into a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Stir gently to combine. If wished, small dried rosebuds can be included for appearance. Ensure that these are organic too.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to suitable airtight containers.
steps.description: Label and date so that you remember when it was made and when it should be used by.

steps.headline: Leave for a few days for the rose petals to begin imparting a little flavour.
steps.description: Most of the flavour will come out with the hot water when the tea is made though, so there's no need to wait too long.

steps.headline: Make the rose tea as for the instructions accompanying the black tea used as the base.
steps.description: The tea will be gently scented with the added rose petals.
